issues.title: Allow file transfer between one's own devices
issues.body:
This feature seems like it should be implemented: one already can do this by copy-pasting her/his link after upload, but it is not convenient. And this feature contributes to convenience a lot. If this is not possible because of some sort of policy or anything else, it would be really nice to at least have QR code on upload page, so there's no need to type link manually on another device.

And please, keep in mind that not each LAN allows connected devices to communicate directly, one does not carry around a USB cord/card reader/etc. all the time, so Send could be really useful in such "local" cases, for convenience and security (Unlike sync tools that require configuration or cloud storage services that often keep your very private files unencrypted).

issues.title: Add UTF-8 flag to prevent garbled filename in contents on Windows
issues.body:
When you upload multiple files together uncompressed/unarchived, apparently files are archived as UTF-8 encoded Send-Archive.zip without setting Language encoding flag (EFS).  cf. https://pkware.cachefly.net/webdocs/casestudies/APPNOTE.TXT

As a result these zip files show garbled filenames in contents on Windows.

You can reproduce this problem by uploading 2 files such as "ã‚µãƒ³ãƒ—ãƒ«1-sample1" and "ã‚µãƒ³ãƒ—ãƒ«2-sample2", or whatever containing non-ASCII characters from Windows and downloading it on Windows.

Although I have not tested, maybe it can be fixed by changing
`v.setUint16(6, 8, true); // bit flags (8 = use data descriptor)`
to
`v.setUint16(6, 2056, true); // bit flags (2056 = use data descriptor(8) + utf8-encoded(2048))`
in https://github.com/mozilla/send/blob/master/app/zip.js#L32

issues.title: Look into implementing tus.io open protocol, again
issues.body:
It would be better if Chunked Upload strategy is used instead of WebSockets streaming.
WebSocket approach currently used has many problems.

Chunked Upload strategy uses raw HTTP protocol it benefits from future advancements in underlying protocol (HTTP/3 which has extremely better data streaming). Unlike WebSocket which is tied to the TCP protocol.

As mentioned in #551 , [tus.io](https://tus.io) is a great open protocol, it would be better if it's [Node server](https://github.com/tus/tus-node-server) implementation gets revived, rather than reinventing the wheel by creating a new server implementation.

Or, Go implementation [tusd](https://github.com/tus/tusd) can be used if that's possible?

Number users of Firefox Send has increased than it had in 2017 (when that ticket was opened) it would be better if it's functionality gets improved now.

![firefox-send](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6831775/68133503-c8897a00-ff20-11e9-8885-8d88633c1651.gif)

I'd like to have a quick and easy way to send files directly to one or many of my own devices. For example, I take a picture on my phone and want to send this to my laptop. While it is quite easy to just open FF Send and click download, I'd like to make that even easier.

issues.title: Fenix doesn't work with Send
issues.body:
Originally filed as mozilla-mobile/fenix#3336.

### Steps to reproduce

1. upload a file to send.firefox.com
2. copy the download URL
3. open the download URL
4. press the "Download" button
5. confirm that you want to download the file

### Expected behavior

Fenix downloads the file properly.

### Actual behavior

Fenix downloads a file with the correct name, but the file is a short text file containing `Unauthorized`.

---

Firefox Preview currently performs downloads in two steps. Gecko find out about the download, then our Android Components library fetches the resource. This behaviour doesn't work properly with Send.

This issue has previously been investigated, and currently Send whitelists Firefox Preview in the Service Worker and treats it similar to Safari. However the issue is still occuring in Firefox Preview.

I'd recommend the team try using the [Android emulator](https://developer.android.com/studio/run/emulator) and install the latest APK from [Fenix releases](https://github.com/mozilla-mobile/fenix/releases) to see this happen. I can help with setting up the emulator.

issues.title: Insecure password storage: KDF with low PBKDF2 iterations and HMAC with fixed nonce
issues.body:
In #607 a concern was raised by @ehuggett about an insufficient number of iterations for the PBKDF2 function as used for processing the *authentication* password. This key is not used for *encryption* if users think so.

I think it is realistic to assume that the share URL (file.url) can be compromised at some point (e.g. because a conversation/email was leaked). If the KDF output is leaked, then 100 iterations is not sufficient.

For others wondering, the password is only used for authentication to the server, it is not used for encryption. So if (1) the URL gets leaked and (2) the server storage gets leaked, then the password has no use.

The encryption details are described at https://github.com/mozilla/send/blob/master/docs/encryption.md, but it is unfortunately rather vague about the exact parameters (hash function, iterations) and the data that is actually sent and stored on the server. **Suggestion**: update that document such that an analysis can be done without requiring digging through the source code.

The client code that uses the password is here:
https://github.com/mozilla/send/blob/3b8dbfd81c05c1ec26e609d77ee6a0ec67bac32d/app/keychain.js#L110-L120
The server code is right here:
https://github.com/mozilla/send/blob/63ddbeefc40e2ae52a603eedd463145540ffe114/server/middleware/auth.js#L12-L32

If I am not mistaken, the data flow when an a password is set is as follows:
```
// example user input
passwordKey = "user supplied password here"
shareUrl = "https://send.firefox.com/download/c5763857606a7cef/#38KeHMXW30zbPOC9aQ-CBQ"

salt = shareUrl
iterations = 100
authKey = PBKDF2(SHA-256, passwordKey, salt, iterations)
nonce = base64-decode("yRCdyQ1EMSA3mo4rqSkuNQ==")
verifyHash = HMAC-SHA256(authKey, nonce)
```

The fixed nonce occurs because `KeyChain` is constructed with no parameters. This fixed nonce is subsequently sent over the websocket which is presumably stored in plain on the server, see https://github.com/mozilla/send/blob/master/app/fileSender.js. I verified with a debugger that the nonce is fixed.

So assuming that:
- The server storage is compromised and leaks metadata (nonce, verifyHash).
- The URL is leaked
- The analysis is correct and a fixed nonce is stored together with verifyHash

Then an attacker can bruteforce the original password due to the very low iteration count.

issues.body: I'm presented with the login window on https://send.firefox.com/ after clicking the "Sign in/up" button (in the upper right-hand corner). My first reaction is: but I'm already signed in to Firefox Accounts! Why do I have to sign in again?? Incidentally, if you click the "Sign in/up" form but **leaving the email input field empty**, it takes me to the familiar FxA page at `https://accounts.firefox.com/oauth/?action=email&client_id=1f30e32975ae5112&code_challenge=hsZ2...` where it knows I was already logged in. I always struggle to remember which email address I use to Sign in to Firefox. Is it my personal or my work/LDAP one or my Gmail addrress?? For that reason I dislike having to type in my email on the sign up form. From FxA page I just need to click "Sign in" and I become logged in on send.firefox.com

issues.title: Implement a WebExtension and some client libraries for different languages
issues.body:
Implementation of encryption in JavaScript turns all the security into snake oil. Users cannot be sure that the code available on the webpage is not malware. So the code used should be the same for all the websites and there should be guarantees that it is not backdoored.

A possible way to solve the issue is to implement a WebExtension. When a website supporting Mozilla Send is loaded, the extension detects it and no content from the website is executed or shown. Instead the extension opens its own GUI and does all the work itself, interacting to the website via API when needed. No third party libs (including vendored ones), frameworks and WebAssembly blobs is allowed in the extension, only Vanilla JS and API provided by the browser. Extension is not attested, it is just installed by a user, audited by him and can be modified by him without preventing it from operation.

issues.title: Allow users to transfer very large files without storing them server-side
issues.body:
As a user, I'm still struggling to share very large files with others. Send currently has a 1gb upload limit, which is too small for some legitimate use cases, like sharing a collection of RAW photos from a trip. No good alternative exists on the Internet today, and my attempts at coding this myself [have somehow failed again](https://twitter.com/jvehent/status/1024277240685756416).

@warner's [magic wormhole](https://github.com/warner/magic-wormhole/) offers a very elegant solution to this problem, but the tool is terminal-based and not suitable to the general population. A [web version](https://github.com/warner/magic-wormhole/issues/9) was discussed a long time ago, but never came to fruition. I think Send could be that web version.

**User Story**
User A wants to send a very large file (50GB) to user B. A uploads the file to send.firefox.com and get a warning: the file is too large to be uploaded, but can be transferred to B directly. A URL is provided, and a message informs A to keep the tab open until B is done transferring.

A sends the URL to B who opens it up in a browser. The Send server then establishes a channel between A and B, uploads the file from A and transfers the chunks directly to B. Nothing is stored or cached on the server side. Encryption principles that normally apply to files uploaded to Send remain in effect and only encrypted chunks are transferred, then decrypted by B.

I think this feature would solve a real problem Internet users encounter regularly. As someone who supports photographers who have to deal with huge files on a daily basis, I can attest to the need for a service that makes transferring these large archives much more easily.

issues.title: Define the browser support matrix
issues.body:
What is the intended browser support matrix for https://send.firefox.com?

I found the note in the FAQ, [_Why is my browser not supported?_](https://github.com/mozilla/send/blob/master/docs/faq.md#why-is-my-browser-not-supported) which pointed me towards the WebCrypto API. Unfortunately [MDN's compatibility table](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Web_Crypto_API#Browser_compatibility) is missing a lot of data.

I'm asking because in https://github.com/projectfluent/fluent.js/issues/133 we're considering dropping the support for old versions of Chrome and Firefox as well as the support for IE11. Fluent is used the localize the Firefox Send website. Dropping the support would mean that the `fluent/compat` builds might contain async functions and `function*` generators, which cause syntax errors in browsers which don't support them.

Here's the list of browser versions we're currently considering supporting in Fluent's `compat` builds:

    Firefox >= 52,
    Chrome >= 55,
    Edge >= 15,
    Safari >= 10.1,
    iOS >= 10.3

issues.title: Uploading a file close to but less than max_file_size always fails
issues.body:
- Observed on a local v1.1.2 server
- Uploading a file exactly equal to max_file_size always fails
- Files which are not rejected by the client (as they are less than max_file_size) are rejected by the server after the user has posted the data
- with max_file_size set to 1024 (bytes) I was unable to send a file larger than 1008 bytes
- with max_file_size set to 1040 (bytes) I was unable to send a file larger than 1024 bytes
- I suspect the (**16 byte**) gcm tag the webCryptoApi appends to the encrypted data for us may be responsible for the mismatch (27.4 Encrypt point 7 https://www.w3.org/TR/WebCryptoAPI/#aes-gcm-operations).

It seems we need to either add 16 to
https://github.com/mozilla/send/blob/74718d6361b83148294628aff3ae5943cab822b9/server/routes/index.js#L50
or subtract 16 from the value the client will use for max file size (which seems to have been removed? I can't find it to link here at least)

issues.title: Sending the link from send using "Send Tab" is awkward.
issues.body:
This is a mouthful of an issue title. Sorry. I don't see an issue for this, but it's related to #511, sort of.

Currently, the URL only appears in `<input>` and so if you want to use it with Send Tab, a user has to copy the link, open it in a tab, and then send that tab. This is kind of annoying and would be relatively easy to make better:

If it appeared in an `<a>` (maybe below the `<input>`?), "Send Link to device" would be available in a context menu, and you could send it directly.

issues.title: Enable smoother signin if the user is signed in to Firefox on mobile
issues.body:
If the user is already signed in to Firefox on their mobile device, it should be possible to streamline the process of signing in to the Send app on the same device.  Fennec provides an "AuthProvider" interface that allows it to share its login state out to other apps, see e.g. how Lockwise integrated with it here:

  https://github.com/mozilla-lockwise/lockwise-android/pull/879

Please consider adding something similar to the Send mobile app.

Note that I don't think it's possible to automagically sign in to Send using the data that's stored in Fennec, because Send uses a distinct encryption key from the one that Fennec holds for Sync. But it should be possible to at least pre-fill the user's email address and perhaps avoid asking for email confirmation or 2FA.

issues.title: OAuth 2.0 / Keycloak suppot
issues.body:
We ar eusing Keycloak as an Open Source Identity and Access Management. 

Is it possible to use something like Keycloak (via OAuth 2.0?) instead of a FXA server for user logins of Mozilla Send? As far as I can see in the config file, we can only specify a link to an FXA server together with a client id.

If an FXA server is required: Can we use the one from Mozilla and - if yes - how can we obtain a client id?

issues.title: Ability to send text
issues.body:
Sorry if this is covered somewhere and I missed it.  

Can Send support raw text strings, without the need of a file?

Sometimes it is desirable to send just a raw string. Maybe a credit card or social security number. At the moment a user would have to create a text file for this purpose, and although that works, it is inconvenient. It'd be nice to be able to just securely enter and send raw text.

issues.title: Query flags to auto-download and display file
issues.body:
This is a feature request. I'm proposing two new flags to be added that modify the behaviour of the file download page.

Format:
`https://send.firefox.com/download/FILE/?autodl=1&display=1#KEY`

Key description:
- **`autodl`** - if set to `1` and file isn't password-protected, automatically download the file (same as clicking the dl btn)
- **`display`** - if set to `1` and the above conditions are true, display the file in-tab. This is extremely useful for images

This allows for a somewhat complete cli to be built without requiring the end-client to also have an interpreter.

issues.title: Support sharing a folder
issues.body: This is useful when you have a folder to share. Yes, you could zip it, but for non tech-savvy users it's better to just drag & drop a folder.

issues.title: [Enhancement] Multiple Password Access
issues.body:
I have a use case that we are evaluating Firefox Send to be an alternative to sharing about:support information in the support.mozilla.org forums. 

Right now, there is a limit in characters to paste the full about:support info, and the user can share private information. [[Bug 1484295#c13](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1484295#c13)]

An ideal use case would be to have the option to have the password protection to work more than once or have a set time to expire instead of password protection. 
(Other enhancement ideas on how to solve for use case welcome)

issues.title: How to use custom S3 Endpoint?
issues.body:
I host my own minio server (compatible with S3).  I get this error:

```
FirefoxSend.send.upload.ERROR: upload NoSuchBucket: The specified bucket does not exist
```

This is likely reaching out to the "real" Amazon S3.  How can I point this to my local S3?  Ideally I could set an environment variable such as: AWS_S3_ENDPOINT

I am starting the server with the following command:
```
S3_BUCKET="phpdave11.bucket" npm run start 
```

prs.title: modify connect-src of Content Security Policy to include dynamic wss URL based on configured base URL
prs.body:
When serving Firefox Send from a domain of our own, uploads were failing on the following browsers:

- iOS Firefox
- iOS Chrome
- iOS Safari
- Mac Safari

This resolves the issue by generating a proper wss URL for the connect-src CSP directive. Since the default value of `base_url` in the config is `https://send.firefox.com`, the directive will be identical to its value before this change if the `BASE_URL` environment variable is not set

prs.title: Update and make deployment doc easier to understand
prs.body:
*Summary*

Update the deployment documentation with easier to understand terms and examples. Also, provide a more secure way to deploy Firefox Send.

*Additional Notes*

* While the deployment doc was enough to deploy Firefox Send on Debian/Ubuntu with Apache, it lake critical information that made me scratch my head several minutes before finally figuring it out. I used information from #1356 and #1221 .
* I also rewrote it using a slightly more secure way of launching the running script, without giving shell access to `www-data`.
* Lastly, I added a section about TLS certificate. While not directly related to Firefox Send, it's probably something a lot of people want to do, and something we should recommend as much as possible.
